captions.text:
Relativity - the idea that everything is relative,
right? Relative to your perspective, your

upbringing, your age, your place and orientation
in space and time? Except that plenty of things
- in fact, perhaps most things - aren't relative.

For example, George Washington was the first
president of the United States, World War

I happened before the movie Star Wars was
made, this picture shows three apples, and
so on.

It is true that certain things ARE relative
to one's perspective - is the apple on your

left, or my right? - is 50°F hot or cold?
- is a car fast or slow? big or small? - and

that's precisely what makes these concepts
less interesting to scientists. In physics

(and in most science), anything that changes
if you change perspective can't be a fundamental

property of the universe - only things that
are absolute are considered 'physical' or

And for a long time, physicists thought that
distances in space and intervals of time were
absolute, fundamental properties in the universe.

The special theory of relativity first described
by Albert Einstein was merely a statement

of the realization that we were wrong: distances
in space and time are actually relative - they

change depending on how fast you're moving.
But more importantly, Einstein also described

several quantities related to space and time
which *are* absolute: the distance between

two events in spacetime, the energy-momentum
of an object, and of course, the speed of
light.

Similarly, the general theory of relativity
was essentially the recognition that in fact

neither the acceleration nor the gravitational
force experienced by an object are absolute

quantities. Accelerations can transform into
gravitational fields (and vice versa), depending

on your perspective and the path you take
through spacetime. The more fundamental absolute

quantity is the *curvature* of spacetime,
which you can think of as a kind of "underlying"
or "absolute" gravity.

Special and General relativity, are, at their
core, not about what's relative - they're

about what's real irrespective of perspective.
If everything were relative, then there could

be no science, no laws, no justice - just
opinion.

Science exists because it turns out there
*are* absolutes in the universe - truths which

are the same regardless of your perspective.
You might even say that science is simply

about finding the truths that will still be
true if you remove
the scientist. So... goodbye!

comments.text:
In the real world, the speed of light is relative (variable) - it does 
depend on the speed of the light source, as predicted by Newton's emission 
theory of light. Unfortunately we all live in Einstein's world where the 
speed of light is, by postulation, constant (independent of the speed of 
the light source), and space and time are disfigured so as to form an 
efficient "protecive belt" around the false postulate:

http://bertie.ccsu.edu/naturesci/PhilSci/Lakatos.html 
 "Lakatos distinguished between two parts of a scientific theory: its "hard 
core" which contains its basic assumptions (or axioms, when set out 
formally and explicitly), and its "protective belt", a surrounding 
defensive set of "ad hoc" (produced for the occasion) hypotheses. (...) In 
Lakatos' model, we have to explicitly take into account the "ad hoc 
hypotheses" which serve as the protective belt. The protective belt serves 
to deflect "refuting" propositions from the core assumptions..." 

http://philosophy.ru/edu/ref/sci/lakatos.html 
 Imre Lakatos, Falsification and the Methodology of Scientific Research 
Programmes: "All scientific research programmes may be characterized by 
their 'hard core'. The negative heuristic of the programme forbids us to 
direct the modus tollens at this 'hard core'. Instead, we must use our 
ingenuity to articulate or even invent 'auxiliary hypotheses', which form a 
protective belt around this core, and we must redirect the modus tollens to 
these. It is this protective belt of auxiliary hypotheses which has to bear 
the brunt of tests and get adjusted and readjusted, or even completely 
replaced, to defend the thus-hardened core."

Banesh Hoffmann is quite clear: the Michelson-Morley experiment confirms 
the variable speed of light predicted by Newton's emission theory of light 
unless there is a protective belt ("contracting lengths, local time, or 
Lorentz transformations") that deflects the refuting experimental evidence 
from the false constant-speed-of-light postulate:

http://books.google.com/books?id=JokgnS1JtmMC 
 "Relativity and Its Roots", Banesh Hoffmann, p.92: "Moreover, if light 
consists of particles, as Einstein had suggested in his paper submitted 
just thirteen weeks before this one, the second principle seems absurd: A 
stone thrown from a speeding train can do far more damage than one thrown 
from a train at rest; the speed of the particle is not independent of the 
motion of the object emitting it. And if we take light to consist of 
particles and assume that these particles obey Newton's laws, they will 
conform to Newtonian relativity and thus automatically account for the null 
result of the Michelson-Morley experiment without recourse to contracting 
lengths, local time, or Lorentz transformations. Yet, as we have seen, 
Einstein resisted the temptation to account for the null result in terms of 
particles of light and simple, familiar Newtonian ideas, and introduced as 
his second postulate something that was more or less obvious when thought 
of in terms of waves in an ether."﻿

comments.text:
+Алексей Салихов I'm not aware of any outside observer involved in 
relativity. The point is, as far as you are concerned, when you run, the 
earth seems to be moving instead of you. It sounds absurd to claim that you 
are indeed standing still and the earth is the one moving, but you must 
take into account that earth is traveling around the sun at roughly 42,000 
miles per hour, and if you happened to be running in the opposite direction 
than this orbit, you would be moving less quickly than the earth—RELATIVE 
TO THE SUN. And of course, the earth could also be standing still relative 
to the Milky Way, since the sun is orbiting our galaxy, and the two 
relative speeds cancel. We have no idea how our galaxy is moving relative 
to the universe, and we have no idea what to call the epicenter of the 
universe anyway. As you see, it's impossible to measure concrete velocities 
through space, because there is no concrete point of reference. That's why 
all motion has to be relative.

The velocity of light also has to be relative, because it has fairly 
concrete speeds, depending on the substance through which it travels. 
That's why you could theoretically have a spacecraft traveling at near 
light speed towards a star, and the light waves from the star, being 
compressed, would undergo a blue Doppler shift, while light could bounce 
normally within the spacecraft. The relativity of light starts to make less 
sense, however, when you take into consideration objects moving in the 
opposite direction, adding up to a relative greater-than-light-speed.

people on the train and that of the people watching from outside the train.

is the absolute truth. Whether the light reaches both sides of the train at 
the same time or not is the aspect that is relative given someone's 
position in spacetime. The event of light appearing at the center of the 
train and eventually hitting both ends is absolute with regards to 
spacetime. Additionally, the speed of light is a constant that does not 
change based on your relative position in spacetime because light travels 
entirely through space and not through time. Its speed is calculated 
against absolute spacetime and not relative space or relative time.

comments.text:
+Andrew Carlisle
As a practical matter, even having it happen over 98 seconds instead of 1 
second, you're still taking about an energy transfer (say, if all that 
object's kinetic energy where given off as heat) that's equivalent to all 
the energy coming out of 200 copies of the Sun for more than a minute and a 
half. In other words, the object is vaporized into a plasma. But let's 
leave that aside.

It's an interesting thought experiment. Some observations:
1. Your scenario shouldn't include an observer pressing a button, since 
that introduces of the issue of the time for that action to causally 
influence other locations in your scenario. Instead, declare that the 
entire slowing-down-mechanism was preset to activate so that it began, in 
the lab frame, when B reached the origin (the tip of the barrel of the 
gun), and manifested a constant deceleration of point A, as measured in the 
lab frame, to where A came to rest in 98 seconds.
2. You'll need some assumptions as in #1, because lab-measured deceleration 
of different points on the object is not going to be constant. The 
deceleration mechanism must be applied along the entire object and with 
different extents in order to achieve the lab-measured stopping of the 
entire object in 98 seconds. You can't make an assumption about applying a 
force at one point and having the entire rigid body react accordingly, 
these speeds are dwarfing the speed of sound through the object.
3. With 1 and 2 in mind, the scenario remains set up so that, in the lab 
frame, A undergoes constant deceleration, from its initial speed to 0, in a 
certain time, and that this deceleration begins at the same time (lab 
frame) as when B reaches the origin. So in the lab, at time =0, both A and 
B are moving in the positive x direction at velocity v, B is at the origin, 
and A is at x = L/gamma (where L is the object's rest length, and gamma is 
1 over square root 1 minus v-squared over c-squared). At time t=0, the 
stopping mechanism along the entire rigid body kicks in, and slows the 
whole thing down so that:
i) In the lab, by construction of the stopping mechanism, point A 
decelerates uniformly from velocity v to 0 in time T.
ii) The stopping mechanism is designed so that object doesn't undergo any 
internal change as seen by an observer riding the object. It isn't 
stretched or crushed according to an observer inside it.
Yes, that appears to me to be a physically valid gedanken experiment.

So here's the setup as in #3: Let t = lab time and xA(t) = lab position of 
A, and xB(t) = lab position of B.
Then by construction, xA(t) = (L/gamma) + vt + 1/2 a t^2, where a = -v/T. 
Also  xB(0) = 0.
So, xA(T) = (L/gamma) + 1/2 v T, and it seems that xB(T) = xA(T) - L, (the 
minus L is because the object didn't deform and is now at rest when t=T, so 
the lab measures its length to be its rest length).
So it seems that xB(T) = (-1+1/gamma)L + 1/2 v T.
Question #1: Find xB(t), and so xB(T). 
Question #2: If arrange numbers so that xB(T) = L(-1+1/gamma) + 1/2 v T < 
0, then B ended up to the left of the origin. Does this make sense? Is 
there a contradiction there somewhere?
Problem With Question2: If this is a physically valid scenario, the xB(t) 
will be a smooth function. From xB'(0) = v > 0, xB(0)=0, and xB(T)<0, can 
deduce from xB(t) being smooth that there exists some time t0, 0<t0<T such 
that xB'(t0)=0 and xB(t0)>0. Why can't we just stop B at t0? Why,  in order 
to stop A, do we have to stop B, and then make B move the opposite 
direction? It seems like that shouldn't be necessary in order to stop A.

Observation #1: Condition ii, that an observer riding on the object sees no 
distortion of the object, is the complicating factor. Ordinary special 
relativity, with its nice constant velocities, makes everything into nice 
clean vector spaces and linear transformations between them. If I recall, 
Condition ii and constant acceleration of a frame change the coordinates 
describing where a point (event) is from being nice straight (if slanted) 
lines to being hyperbolas. In order to decelerate the object while not 
deforming it, the lab-measured deceleration won't be uniform across the 
object.
Observation #2: As in #1, Einstein's Equivalence Principle says that an 
acceleration can be identified with free-fall under the effect of gravity. 
Thus the math here is going to look like the math of General Relativity. As 
with Observation#1, it means that you've got some complicated "metric" 
describing the math and the relation between the lab frame and the 
accelerating frame.
Observation #3: I believe any accelerating frame of reference creates a 
"horizon" like the event horizon of a black hole (one whose consequences 
are so small-distant as to be ignorable for ordinary small speeds and 
accelerations). In your example, if we forget about the object for a

+Andrew Carlisle
Re: "The fact that A can experimentally confirm that B is moving away 
faster than light using the information from the observer who is at rest 
does not violate relativity.  Is this what you are saying?"
No. A can experimentally measure B's speed, and it's *not* faster than the 
speed of light. You seem fixated on the assumptions that there's an 
objective meaning of speed that's computed in a classical way, but the 
whole point of relativity is that those assumptions are false. There's only 
the speed as measured in a given inertial frame.
.
Re: "Another question...Does relativity place an upper limit on the 
acceleration that can be applied to an object?"
I don't think that Special Relativity puts a bound on measured 
acceleration, other than the obvious one that a very rapid acceleration 
can't last too long because otherwise the measured speed would exceed the 
speed of light. General Relativity is a different matter. Quantum Mechanics 
is a different matter still (see Unruh Effect). But for just Special 
Relativity, I don't think there's a theoretical bound on sufficiently brief 
accelerations. I've never thought about it before, so maybe I'm missing 
something, but I don't see a problem with it.

You are right. But c being the maximum velocity means that it is the 
maximum relative to a rest frame. Both the speeds you described are below c 
relative to the rest frame you view them from, B's rest frame. Adding them 
together gives something larger than c, but that only describes how fast B 
sees them approaching each other. They still move slower than c relative to 
B's frame.

If you were to use Lorentz transformation to find what speeds body A 
measures, you would would be viewing the situation from A's rest frame. In 
that frame A has zero speed. You'd also find that the previous observer B, 
and the body C have speeds that are below c, relative to A's rest frame, 
such that again no speeds above c occur. The same thing is of course also 
true if you view it from C's rest frame.

The explanation to why this happens lies within the Lorentz transformation, 
so I
suggest you check those out if you want a better understanding ;)

comments.text:
Having studied General Relativity with a professor whose's speciality was 
general relativity, I was taught some of the many misconceptions. 

Einstein explained that acceleration is indistinguishable from gravity in a 
LIMITED reference frame.  They are NOT equivalent.  Consider the often used 
thought experiment of an elevator falling towards earth.  The persons 
within the elevator are in free fall, so it seems like the acceleration 
perfectly balances out the gravitational field.  Thus the common belief 
that the acceleration is equivalent to a gravitational field.  But, place 
two balls as far apart as you can within the elevator.  As the elevator 
approaches earth, the balls are attracted to the centre of the earth, so 
they move in two lines that are not exactly parallel.  These two balls will 
approach each other more rapidly than can be defined by the gravitational 
force between them.  Given enough precision, enough time, a large enough 
elevator ( so the balls are VERY far apart), it would be possible to 
discern the actual existence of a gravitational object, and realize that 
you must be in free-fall, and are accelerating.  

Mathematically, the curvature of space in an accelerating reference frame 
can be reworked to an 'flat' space-time, whereas this cannot be done for a 
gravitational field.﻿

object, an apple being an absolute would mean that even if there'd never

properties stipulated by the idea of 'apple'. This platonic view of the

It is in questioning the preconceptions on which we base our understanding 
that we evolve our understanding.﻿
